title: How to Make Elderberry Syrup

steps.headline: Rinse off ½ cup (100 g) of dried elderberries and remove any twigs.
steps.description: Place the dried elderberries in a colander and rinse them off thoroughly with cold water. If you see any twigs, remove them. Elderberries contain a toxin that cooking will eliminate, and getting rid of twigs makes the cooking process easier and more effective. Never consume uncooked fresh or dried elderberries. They contain a very dangerous cyanide-like toxin.

steps.headline: Combine the elderberries and distilled water in a large saucepan.
steps.description: Transfer the dried elderberries into a large pot or saucepan. Measure out 1 quart (947 ml) of cold distilled water and pour it over the elderberries. Then, place the saucepan on your stovetop. If you have time, let the elderberries soak in the water for 30-60 minutes before proceeding. This softens them up a bit, but it isn’t required. Don’t use water from the tap. If you don’t have distilled water, you can use purified or spring water.Did You Know? Pans with synthetic non-stick coatings may release unwanted chemicals into the syrup. It's best to use a ceramic, glass, or other non-reactive saucepan for this project.

steps.headline: Cook the elderberries over medium heat for 30-45 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the burner to medium heat and let the mixture cook uncovered for up to 45 minutes, or until the berries are soft and pliant. Stir the mixture every 5-10 minutes to prevent the berries from sticking. Do not cover the saucepan in an effort to speed up the process. It’s important that the berries cook for the full amount of time to eliminate the cyanide-like toxin inside of them.

steps.headline: Remove the saucepan from heat and let the mixture cool for 1 hour.
steps.description: Once the berries are soft, take the saucepan off the burner and place it on a heat-safe surface. Let the berries steep in the hot water and allow the water to cool to room temperature.

steps.headline: Place a cheesecloth over a large bowl and strain the mixture.
steps.description: Position a cheesecloth or double muslin bag over the mouth of a bowl and pour the cooled mixture onto it. To speed up the process and yield as much extract as possible, you can gather the corners of the cheesecloth up and squeeze it to force the extract into the bowl. You should end up with about 2 cups (473 ml) of extract. Discard the spent elderberries.

steps.headline: Combine the elderberry extract with honey in the large saucepan.
steps.description: Transfer the elderberry extract back into the large saucepan. Measure out 1 ½ cups (355 ml) of honey or brown rice syrup and add it to saucepan with the extract. Stir the ingredients together thoroughly. You could also use glycerin or a simple sugar solution instead of honey, if you prefer.

steps.headline: Boil the ingredients for 10-30 minutes until the mixture gets thick.
steps.description: Turn the heat to high and bring the ingredients to a boil. Once the mixture is boiling, let it continue to boil uncovered for 10-30 minutes. You can remove the saucepan from the heat once the mixture gets thick and syrupy. You will end up with approximately 3 ½ cups (828 ml) of syrup.

steps.headline: Let the syrup cool and pour it into a sterilized glass jar.
steps.description: Remove the saucepan from the heat and let the syrup cool for about half an hour. Then, use a funnel to transfer the syrup into a glass jar with an airtight lid. Screw the lid on tightly. The syrup can be lukewarm; it doesn’t have to cool completely to room temperature before you bottle it. You can use a regular glass jar or an amber-colored glass jar with a dropper for easy dosing.

steps.headline: Store the syrup in your refrigerator for up to 3 months.
steps.description: As long as you keep the syrup in an airtight jar and in your fridge, homemade elderberry syrup should remain shelf stable and effective for up to 3 months. You may want to label the jar with the date you made the syrup so that you don’t forget.Tip: Clearly label the jar so that the elderberry syrup is not mistaken for regular maple syrup.

steps.headline: Take 1-2 teaspoons (5-10 ml) of syrup every day for immune support.
steps.description: You don’t need to take the syrup year-round, but it may be a helpful preventative measure during cold and flu season. Simply dip the teaspoon right into the syrup or use a dropper to measure it out. There is no standard dose for elderberry syrup. This dose is only recommended for adults. Keep in mind that the safety of long-term use isn’t known.

steps.headline: Increase the dose to 1 tablespoon (15 ml) 4 times daily at the first sign of illness.
steps.description: Elderberry syrup is thought to be most effective if taken 24-48 hours before a cold or flu strikes, so start taking 1 tablespoon (15 ml) 4 times per day as soon as you start feeling symptoms. The syrup may decrease the duration of the sickness and ease symptoms like fever, cough, headache, and sore throat. This is the recommended dose for an adult.

steps.headline: Avoid giving elderberry syrup to children and pregnant women.
steps.description: If you want to give the syrup to a child, talk to your doctor for dosage advice. In general, the syrup isn’t recommended for children, since the safety of the supplement hasn’t been studied enough. Pregnant and breastfeeding women shouldn’t risk it. If you take other medications, talk to your doctor before starting this supplement. Elderberry may negatively interact with chemo medications, immuno-suppressant drugs, diuretics, and laxatives.
